newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Zimbabwe inflation rises, seen in 16-18 pct range.
newsitem.headline: Zimbabwe inflation rises, seen in 16-18 pct range.

text.p: Zimbabwe's annual inflation rose to 16.4 percent in December from a seven-year low of 13.9 percent in November, in line with forecasts by many local economic analysts.

Although a recent spate of price increases, including the cost of fuel, are expected to feed January's inflation figure, many analysts still expect annual inflation to stay in a 16-18 percent range in the first quarter of 1997.
The December rate from the state Central Statistical Office (CSO) left the average monthly inflation rate for 1996 at 21.7 percent compared with 22.5 percent the previous year.
It was also below the 20 percent forecast for the year-end in the country's 1996/97 budget.
Savvas Kyriakides, managing director of economic and share market analysts Dataworld, said the monthly inflation rate would be kept in check by low food prices.
Food accounts for 29.2 percent of Zimbabwe's inflation basket, the largest single weighting.
"We are expecting a bumper harvest...and that should balance off other areas," Kyriakides told Reuters.
Zimbabwe's farm-based economy is expected to grow by seven percent this year, up from an estimated five percent in 1996, on the back of a good agricultural season.

John Robertson, one of the country's leading economic consultants, also said the December figure was widely expected, but maintaining it in a 16-18 percent range would depend on how President Robert Mugabe's government managed to control spending and money supply growth.
"There is still a lot of work to be done in this area," he said.
Last November, Zimbabwe's central Reserve Bank raised to 20 percent from 17.5 percent the statutory reserves banks are required to keep with it.
The central bank said the measure was aimed at tightening money supply growth -- which has remained stubbornly above a target of 22 percent per year fixed under economic reforms started in 1991.
That growth, many local analysts say, threatens efforts to keep inflation down. Wage increases later in the year may also fuel inflation. ---Harare Newsroom: +263-4 72 52 27/8/9.---
